Subjective: Headache for about 2 months.
Headache mainly on the right side.
Headache sometimes diffuses.
Headaches are increasing in severity.
Headaches occur almost weekly.
Headache episodes last for several days.
Severe headaches are accompanied by nausea.
No vomiting during headache episodes.
Headaches are accompanied by glare in the field of vision.
Headaches are not accompanied by flashes of light.
Headaches improve in a dark room.
Patient uses paracetamol for headaches.
Patient uses ibuprofen for headaches.
Ibuprofen is more effective than paracetamol.
No clear stress trigger.
No clear coffee trigger.
No clear energy drink trigger.
Family history: father with migraine.
Family history: grandfather with cluster headaches.
Patient wants to know if the symptoms are consistent with migraine.
Patient wants to know if the symptoms are consistent with cluster headaches.
Patient asks about optimal treatment for the headache symptoms.
Objective: Cranial nerves are intact on neurological examination.
Coordination on finger-nose test is normal.
Muscle strength in arms is normal.
Muscle strength in legs is normal.
There is a slight deviation when walking in a straight line.
Assessment: No evidence of a secondary alarming cause of headache.
Plan: Explanation given about the probable diagnosis of migraine.
Advice to take paracetamol at the onset of an attack, up to a maximum of 4x2 tablets per day.
Advice to add ibuprofen if necessary.
Information from Thuisarts.nl about migraine has been discussed with the patient.
Patient advised to keep a headache diary.
Follow-up appointment scheduled in 4 weeks for evaluation and treatment plan.
Advised to contact earlier if symptoms worsen.
Advised to contact earlier if there are changes in the pattern of symptoms.
